item.title: Climate action for software developers and data scientists
item.description: Without action, ICT may exceed 14% of global greenhouse gas emissions by 2040. If you‚Äôre a software developer, and you don‚Äôt have the option‚Ä¶
item.content:encoded:
Without action, ICT may exceed 14% of global greenhouse gas emissions by 2040.1

If you‚Äôre a software developer, and you don‚Äôt have the option to focus on tackling the climate crisis full time, what are the best things you can do in your current role for the environment?

Data centre choice

Data centres are estimated to make up 45% of ICT‚Äôs greenhouse gas emissions. That‚Äôs thought to be similar energy use as the entire aviation industry. Artist/researcher Joana Moll even visualised the trees needed to absorb the CO2 emitted by visits to google.com every second (spoiler: it‚Äôs a lot).

As a software developer, data centre choice is also likely the area you have most influence over. And some options are better than others:

  • ‚ÄúEnterprises choose 100% sustainable locations for new Cloud instances (e.g. use Azure, Google Cloud or the sustainable AWS regions of Dublin, Frankfurt, Oregon or Canada) and transition existing VMs there as soon as possible.
  • Enterprises inform their data center providers they want secure, sustainably-powered compute resources by 2024.
  • Individual technologists state their commitment by signing the Sustainable Servers petition.‚Äù

Source: The State of Data Center Energy Use in 2018

When starting a new project, choosing sustainable servers is likely your highest impact action.

You can check whether your existing projects are powered by renewable energy at The Green Web Foundation.

Efficiency

Writing efficient code, killing old services, remembering not to leave that job running. Business and environmental incentives often align here. But as compute gets cheaper, the pressure to keep server spending down might too.

If you‚Äôre a data scientist, training ML models can be compute intensive, and compute is increasingly cheap. Researchers have suggested two approaches:

  • Measure the carbon footprint of your model with ML CO2 Impact
  • Incentivise Green AI by making efficiency an evaluation criterion for research - aiming to make models greener and more inclusive/accessible with lower training compute requirements

Employee action

At larger tech companies, you might not have as much individual influence over infrastructure. But folk at big tech companies are using collective action to push for better climate outcomes, such as Amazon Employees for Climate Justice, Googler protests against big oil contracts, and the #11at11ClimateStrike. Responses have frustratingly included Amazon firing some of the excellent climate action leaders who spoke up for warehouse workers during the coronavirus pandemic.

Community wisdom

If you‚Äôre keen to make change, it helps not to do it alone.

ClimateAction.tech is a global online community of tech folks using their skills, expertise and platforms to support solutions to the climate crisis. They have an active international Slack and have also held in person meetups in London (pre-COVID).

Software engineers are humans too

Once we‚Äôve automated everyone else‚Äôs jobs, we‚Äôll probably automate our own too. Until then, software engineers are humans, so the highest leverage climate actions for humans apply here too. I summarised evidence-based climate actions for most people here.

Further resources

  • The 8 Principles of Sustainable Software Engineering (20min video)

What‚Äôs missing?

If you think there‚Äôs something missing, I‚Äôd love to hear on Twitter.

  1. Assuming emissions from other sectors remain at 2016 levels.

item.content:encoded:
A note on reading more

Matt Clifford and Nadia Odunayo both write great annual reading lists. They have both inspired me in book choice and in publishing what I‚Äôve enjoyed, but also to be more ambitious in how much I read. Here are a few ways I found to help me read more:

  • Measure what you want to improve: keep an annual list of what you‚Äôve read.
  • Making time by making a habit - replacing mindless timeline scrolling and Netflix by putting the book/Kindle somewhere accessible, and take app icons off my home screen.
  • Put something down if it‚Äôs knocking the habit - I paused a couple of great books (A History of Seven Killings, Destined for War); they‚Äôve been easier to pick up again later, now the habit‚Äôs more cemented.
  • Gamify - I mainly read on Kindle with ‚Äúpercentage of the way through‚Äù and ‚Äútime left in book‚Äù indicators as motivation.

Nonfiction

  • Automating Inequality, Virgina Eubanks
  • Becoming, Michelle Obama
  • Content Design, Sarah Richards
  • Feynman, Jim Ottaviani & Leland Myrick (graphic nonfiction)
  • Open Borders: the Science and Ethics of Immigration - Bryan Caplan & Zach Weinersmith (graphic nonfiction)
  • Superior, Angela Saini
  • World After Capital, Albert Wenger
  • Weapons of Math Destruction, Cathy O‚ÄôNeil

Fiction

  • Parable of the Sower, Octavia E. Butler
  • Homegoing, Yaa Gyasi
  • Station Eleven, Emily St. John Mandel (Update PSA: not recommended during COVID-19 pandemic)
  • Pachinko, Min Jin Lee
  • The Three Body Problem trilogy - Cixin Liu
  • La Belle Sauvage, Phillip Pullman
  • Petals of Blood, Ng≈´gƒ´ Wa Thiong‚Äôo
  • Seveneves, Neal Stephenson
  • Lock In, John Scalzi

Recommendations welcome. Tweet me.

Paper straws are a distraction
item.description: I worry that actions most promoted to help the environment aren‚Äôt the best ones we could take. And that, whilst we congratulate ourselves‚Ä¶
item.content:encoded:
I worry that actions most promoted to help the environment aren‚Äôt the best ones we could take. And that, whilst we congratulate ourselves for using paper straws, moral licensing1 lets us avoid higher impact actions.

I did a little research into I could do better to help the environment and keep the turtles happy:

Highest impact actions for most people

The research2 suggests the best thing we can do as individuals are, in order:

  1. Have one fewer child (massively higher impact than the rest)
  2. Live car free
  3. Avoid one round-trip transatlantic flight
  4. Buy green energy3
  5. Go vegan - eat a plant-based diet

These are pretty different from the common recommendations of recycling and switching off lightbulbs. I‚Äôm pretty bad at some of them (transatlantic flights), and am easily following others (currently both child and car free). I‚Äôm veggie, but not yet vegan.

It surprises me there‚Äôs not more campaigning for switching to green energy, as it seems the easiest of that list to do.

Heuristics for the environment?

I‚Äôd like better heuristics for which actions are best for the environment. Is a paper or plastic bag better?4 Is my cotton bag doing any good?5 Is regular washing of reusable makeup pads better than just buying wipes? Or are the effects so tiny that they‚Äôre not worth the effort versus getting used to the taste of vegan cheese?6

If you have any, I‚Äôd love to hear them on Twitter.

Update 5th July 2019: The Guardian has published a list of recycling heuristics.

  1. When people allow themselves to do something bad, after doing something good - more detail on moral licensing.

    ‚Ü©

  2. Wynes & Nicholas, 2017 Paper, or nice infographic summaries, further interesting discussion in this Vox article.

    ‚Ü©

  3. In the UK, for instance Bulb is green, and appears both cheapest and most user-friendly (that link will get you a discount).

    ‚Ü©

  4. This seems to be non-obvious: ‚ÄòPlastic or paper: Which bag is greener? - BBC‚Äô

    ‚Ü©

  5. Cotton bags get milkshake-ducked by Quartz

    ‚Ü©

  6. The answer seems to be yes: switching from plastic bags to reusable bags ‚Äúis less than 1% as effective as a year without eating meat‚Äù Wynes & Nicholas, 2017 Paper.

item.content:encoded:
I‚Äôve successfully used Twitter to crowdsource resources for people getting into tech. This post documents the results (and saves me scrolling next time someone asks), as well as learnings from the process.

Learning to code resources

I enjoy helping people learn to code, and have spent lots of time mentoring and teaching with organisations like Code First: Girls and 23 Code Street. But that means I‚Äôm often people‚Äôs first introduction to code - instead, I wanted to get an up-to-date idea of the best resources for people doing this remotely. So I turned to Twitter.

The ask:

Hey tech Twitter, what's your favourite online resource to recommend to someone who has never coded before (not even a tiny bit) and wants to see what it's about?

RT for reach üôè ‚ú®

— Jenny Brennan (@jennyhbren) December 9, 2017

I was impressed by the results:

Thank you for wonderful recommendations so far! Tl;dr:

‚≠êÔ∏è @Codecademy topping recommendations
‚≠êÔ∏è @freeCodeCamp next most popular

Honorable mentions:
üî∏ @codeorg
üî∏ @MozDevNet: https://t.co/ENlbP4VQ9A
üî∏ https://t.co/7Eztn3kre4
üî∏ @ftrain's article: https://t.co/rwUYeToQff https://t.co/isicyjBMuU

— Jenny Brennan (@jennyhbren) December 10, 2017

A summary Tweet felt like a good way to:

  • boost reach
  • help people (including myself!) lost in all the replies
  • thank people for their responses

I‚Äôve also seen awesome examples of others doing this, including Jessica Rose, who does this regularly and inspired me in the first place:

Tech Twitter: What are your fav low cost (or free!) tech conferences or events?

RT for reach? Really want to find which events are doing a great job on this üí∏‚ú®

— Jessica Rose (@jesslynnrose) October 16, 2018

And more recently Charlotte Fereday who used Twitter to very quickly gain a lot of contributors to her Coder Newbie Advice GitHub Repository:

Started a repo to help people who want to learn to code for free 3 days ago, with the hope it can help diversify tech. Blown away by support, already had 8 PRs. Pls keep RT-ing & sharing so we can keep growing it: https://t.co/0UVQzjtvNl pic.twitter.com/HmKadXvzIm

— Charlotte Fereday (@CharlotteBRF) October 23, 2018

Getting into cybersecurity

Cybersecurity isn‚Äôt my expertise, but was the interest of a mentee of mine, so, again, I turned to Twitter.

The ask:

Hey tech Twitter, what resources/tips would you recommend to a 17yo who wants to get into cybersecurity?üë©‚Äçüíª Bonus points for online or UK-based.

RT for reach? Thank you üôè ‚ú®

— Jenny Brennan (@jennyhbren) January 7, 2018

The response was fantastic: 120 replies, many detailed and thoughtful, some direct offers of support/conference tickets from senior industry people, and a notable subset who had assumed I was the 17 year old girl üíÅ.

I didn‚Äôt post a summary Tweet this time as the results were hugely diverse, and sometimes contradictory so I‚Äôd recommend working your way through them if cybersecurity‚Äôs your thing.

item.title: Offices have a problem. Period.
item.description: Note: This was originally published on Medium. ‚ÄúHi. We need to talk about sanitary bins.‚Äù Not a common opening line. Not a common first‚Ä¶
item.content:encoded:
Note: This was originally published on Medium.

‚ÄúHi. We need to talk about sanitary bins.‚Äù

Not a common opening line.

Not a common first conversation with a man you‚Äôve never met before, in fact.

But there I was, stood at the office reception.

You see, there‚Äôs fresh sliced fruit in the water tank, beer on tap and a ping pong table‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääbut no sanitary bins in the loos.

The offices are great, and the frontdesk team were diligently trying to solve a mixup with building administration.

But when free mouthwash arrived in the bathrooms, I snapped.

You see, office spaces have a problem with periods. My simple mission had just been to get a sanitary bin in the office before I had my period (that failed). It was an unusual case.

But what is still true: a billion-dollar office space startup pays people to slice fruit into water and now provides free mouthwash in the bathrooms, but doesn‚Äôt leave any tampons in them.

We‚Äôve got some strange priorities.

I don‚Äôt need fruit in my water. I don‚Äôt need beer on tap. But if I‚Äôm bleeding, I need a sanitary product. The number of offices in London I‚Äôve seen freely offering the former (or equivalent) before the latter, is kind of strange.

‚ÄúBut people around the world remember to bring their own‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääyou‚Äôre a grown¬†adult!‚Äù

Yes. But you could bring your own mouthwash too. What companies are saying is ‚Äúwe know that bad breath can make you, or even a client, feel uncomfortable, so it‚Äôs a worthwhile investment to provide this for you, in case you forgot your own solution‚Äù. Sanitary products are a similar investment in employee productivity and, I‚Äôd argue, a much higher priority one 1.

It‚Äôs easily¬†solved.

A number of top tech firms now provide sanitary products, free of charge, in their bathrooms.

Tampon.club calculated the cost of doing so at ¬£4.28 per menstruating individual per year. I‚Äôd estimate the cost of sliced fruit in all the water tanks of one 5 floor swanky shared office building at ¬£6.90 a day (they put lychees in the water one day‚Ää‚Äî‚Äälychees!) 2. 260 days a year. I‚Äôd hazard a guess that a number of such offices in London don‚Äôt yet have 260 menstruating individuals in them. Sanitary products are a good deal. If you don‚Äôt see fruit in the water, you don‚Äôt have to waste office time going out to the shops to get some, or quietly ask a colleague to lend you a lime 3.

And the services exist. Companies like Sanitary Owl in the UK, or Hello Flo in the US, provide monthly home delivery packages, and the latter already provides for a number of US startups.

Happy bleeding resources:

In my accidental side-job as a bathroom campaigner 4, I have come across:

  • Tampon Club‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääresources to help you convince your boss, or provide a community solution instead
  • Free The Tampons‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääif you want to take this a step further and make them free in all public bathrooms
  • Don‚Äôt Let Them See Your Tampons‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääa fun piece on how awkward we often are about hiding sanitary products

(feel free to tweet further resources my way and I‚Äôll add them here)

  1. If it‚Äôs unclear why sanitary products help employee productivity: some people do not have regular periods, so might not be able to anticipate when they need to take a product to the bathroom. Sometimes humans are just forgetful or busy. Walking back to the office to get said product is both time consuming and awkward. Walking to a shop because you don‚Äôt have one in the office and don‚Äôt know anyone to lend you what you need is even more time consuming. Plus, you‚Äôre still bleeding. A large portion of the working population will encounter this issue. Whilst this is also true for bad breath and bad breath is considered socially awkward, bleeding visibly is generally a complete taboo in an office so has a higher cost (plus there‚Äôs usually no social anxiety around asking for mint gum in an office, and plenty of people who could offer it to you).

    ‚Ü©

  2. Each tank: 2 * 24p oranges, 2 x 30p lemons 1 x 30p lime = ¬£1.38. Multiplied by 5 tanks in the office (one for each floor) = ¬£6.90. I have a suspicion they might have added fruit more than once a day, but, equally, they also might have bought it cheaper as regular/wholesale purchasers, so this seems a fair estimate. They also sometimes used watermelon (¬£2.50 a pop). And yes, the water was damn tasty.

    ‚Ü©

  3. Bonus points if you then discover no one else in your team has ever needed a lime. Then you get to ask a stranger for one. True story.

    ‚Ü©

  4. You think I joke. Seriously, why don‚Äôt all public bathrooms have foot step door openers? And why have we never listened to Finland on the way bathroom doors open?

    ‚Ü©
